Scheme 1 Schematic representation of the selective oxidation setup operated under an inductive heating mode. Scheme 1 Fig. 1 (A) Digital photos and SEM images of the carbon felt (CF), with controlled macroscopic shape, and carbon nanotubes (CNT), with high effective surface area but in powdery form which pose problem for handling and transport. (B, C) SEM micrographs of the carbon microfilaments in the carbon felt, (D, E) SEM and TEM micrographs of the carbon nanotubes with nanoscopic dimension and high effective surface area. Inset: High resolution TEM micrograph of the carbon nanotube with concentric graphitic structure. Fig. 1 Fig. 2 SEM images of (A) Carbon felt after heat treatment at 800 °C under helium, (B-D) Carbon nanotubes decorated carbon felt at different synthesis temperature, i.e. (B) 720 °C, (C) 750 °C and (D) 780 °C, (E) High-resolution SEM image of carbon nanotubes network decorated the carbon felt host substrate on the sample synthesized at 750 °C. Fig. 2 Fig. 3 (A) SEM and (B, C, D) TEM images of the CNT@CF composite after synthesis at 750 °C and after HNO3 treatment at 80 °C for the removal of the iron growth catalyst followed by a gaseous HNO3 treatment at 250 °C for 4 h to create structural defects (indicated by arrows in B) which significantly contributes to the large increase of the specific surface area of the final sample. The defects are mainly located on the top surface and the underneath graphene layers remain undamaged as show in Figure (D). Fig. 3 Fig. 4 (A) Survey XPS spectra of the different samples. (B) High-resolution of the XPS O1s spectra of the CNT@CF and o-CNT@o-CF samples. (C) Semi-quantitative analysis of the nature of the oxygen functional groups on the different samples. (D) Raman spectra of the CF, CNT@CF and o-CNT@o-CF samples. Fig. 4 Fig. 5 (A, A1 and A2) Digital photo of the sample connecting and thermal photos of the heat dissipation through the CF and CNT@CF samples upon applying a voltage through the sample. (B) Digital and (C) thermal photos of the reactor under reaction simulation recorded by a FLIR camera showing the high heat targeting of the IH. The targeted heating temperature was set at 230 ± 3 °C and the difference in terms of recorded temperature between the pyrometer and the FLIR camera could be attributed to the loss of the resolution of the FLIR camera due to the presence of the cold coil in the frame. Fig. 5 Fig. 6 Desulfurization performance of the o-CNT@o-CF-750 and o-CF catalysts as a function of time on stream with Joule heating (JH). Reaction conditions: catalyst weight =4 g, [H2S] = 1%, [O2] = 2.5 %, [H2O] = 30 %, O2-to-H2S ratio = 2.5, temperature = 210 °C, space velocity = 20,000 mL. gcat −1. h−1. Full circle: H2S conversion, open circle: sulfur selectivity. Fig. 6 Fig. 7 Desulfurization performance of the O-CNT@O-CF catalyst as a function of the reaction temperature under (A) Joule heating (JH) and (B) inductive heating (IH). Reaction conditions: catalyst weight = 4 g, [H2S] = 1%, [O2] = 2.5 %, [H2O] = 30 %, temperature = 200, 210 and 230 °C, O2-to-H2S ratio = 2.5, GHSV =20,000 mL. gcat −1. h−1. Full circle: H2S conversion, open circle: sulfur selectivity. Fig. 7 Fig. 8 Desulfurization performance of the o-CNT@o-CF catalyst as a function of space velocity under JH and IH mode. Reaction conditions: catalyst weight = 4 g, [H2S] = 1%, [O2] = 2.5 %, [H2O] = 30 %, O2-to-H2S ratio = 2.5, temperature = 230 °C, space velocity = 18,000 (i), 20,000 (ii) and 22,000 mL. gcat −1. h−1 (iii). The H2S conversion under the JH is represented by red dashed line in (B) to highlight the improved desulfurization performance under IH mode. Full circle: H2S conversion, open circle: sulfur selectivity. Fig. 8 Fig. 9 Desulfurization performance of the o-CNT@o-CF-750 catalyst as a function of the O2-to-H2S ratio under JH and IH mode. Institute of Chemistry and Processes for Energy Environment and Health (ICPEES) ECPM UMR 7515 of the CNRS and University of Strasbourg 25 rue Becquerel Strasbourg Cedex 02 67087 France Graphical abstract Hierarchical all carbon metal-free catalyst with controlled macroscopic shape based on the carbon nanotubes decorated carbon felt (CNT@CF) has been prepared. The catalyst was further treated under gaseous nitric acid to generate structural defects on its surface (o-CNT@o-CF). The as-synthesized catalyst was evaluated in the partial oxidation of H2S by oxygen into elemental sulfur in a fixed-bed reactor under a direct and non-contact inductive heating mode. The catalytic results indicate that the o-CNT@o-CF catalyst exhibits an extremely high desulfurization performance under inductive heating mode. The high desulfurization performance was attributed to the high effective heat management inside the catalyst through inductive heating along with a short diffusion length associated with the nanoscopic dimension of the carbon nanotubes. The catalyst also displays a high stability as a function of time on stream. Keywords Inductive heating Hierarchical catalyst Metal-free carbon catalyst Selective oxidation Hydrogen sulfide 1 Introduction Catalysis is a critical step for developing new processes to reduce waste and by-products with respect to the environmental legislations in place nowadays. It is expected that catalysis field will face a fast growth in the decades to come due to the need for improving environmental impact, i.e. new processes with low waste release, and also to reduce as much as possible the energy input. The improvement in catalysis field stems from the development of new and optimized catalysts as well as catalytic processes with better heat and mass transfer management [1]. In the last decades, new approaches based on the use of new heating means with improved heat transfer and control such as microwave or non-thermal plasma have been reported [2–6]. These new heating processes significantly improve the heat targeting to the catalyst which thus, significantly reduces the overall energy input for the catalytic processes and also contributed to an improvement of the overall selectivity of the processes. Induction heating (IH) has recently been reported to be a valid alternative to the traditional indirect Joule heating (JH) approach for operating catalytic processes under kinetic control regime [7,8]. Induction heating allows the heating to take place on electrically conductive catalysts and reduces the heat loss through the whole volume of the reactor as well as through the gaseous reactants as generally encountered with the traditional JH mode. IH displays high efficiency for operating numerous catalytic processes either in liquid- or gas-phase medium according to the recent reports [9–20]. The high heat responsive in the IH mode also allows one to operate the reaction almost under isothermal temperature, even at high reactant flow rate, where a high heat exchange between the catalyst and the gas phase becomes difficult to be maintained by conventional indirect heating. Indeed, in conventional heating the heat was transferred from the oven (gas burner) to the catalyst through conduction, convection and radiation with a large heat loss along the way, while IH provides fast and direct heating of the catalyst solely, if this later is an electrical conductor and thus, active for induction. The rapid heat control, thanks to the high heating/cooling rate of the IH, of the catalyst also prevents the problem of macroscopic temperature runaway which could compromise the safety of the plant. Hydrogen sulfide (H2S) which is originated from natural gas and refinery plants represents a main concern due to its highly corrosive character and its high toxicity which may affect the performance and stability of catalysts downstream of the process [21,22]. H2S also presents high potential hazardous for human health and environment. The complete destruction of H2S in the off-stream gas is thus mandatory for all these reasons. Nowadays, the most used process for the removal of H2S, by converting it into valuable sulfur, is the Claus and selective oxidation processes [23] using medium temperature iron-based catalyst promoted with other elements [24] or low-temperature nickel-based catalysts [25]. However, such iron-based catalysts, either pure or doped, display a relatively sensitivity towards the reaction conditions, i.e. temperature, H2S concentration, O2-to-H2S ratio, as their can irreversibly transform the iron oxide into its corresponding iron sulfide with lower intrinsic activity. The iron-based catalyst also displayed high deactivation behavior in the presence of trace amount of impurities such as aromatics in the processing feed [26]. Since the last decade metal-free catalysts based on carbon-doped with nitrogen have received an increasing scientific interest in numerous catalytic processes due to its high catalytic activity compared to the traditional catalysts based on metals [27–33]. The enhanced catalytic activity of the carbon-based catalysts was attributed to the high dissociative adsorption of the reactants on the activated carbon site localized close to the nitrogen site with electron deficient character. Such electron deficient site has firstly reported by Gong et al. [32] in the oxygen reduction reaction (ORR). Recently, defective carbon-based materials decorated with oxygenated functional groups, generated during the gas-phase acid treatment of the pristine carbon sample, have been reported as potential undoped metal-free catalysts for operating selective H2S oxidation process [34,35]. The main advantage of such carbon-based metal-free catalyst is the avoidance of the use of ammonia at high temperature for the incorporation of nitrogen-doped sites into the catalyst. Indeed, the use of ammonia at high temperature represents some inherent risks for the safety of the process. In addition, for industrial development such carbon-based metal-free active phase should display on one side, a high effective surface area, i.e. carbon filaments with nanoscopic dimension, and a macroscopic shape, on the other side, in order to facilitate transport and handling and to reduce the problem of pressure drop across the catalyst bed [36–38]. Recent work reported by Edouard and co-workers [39] has highlighted the advantages of decorating a foam host matrix with a carbon nanofibers network for operating as structured catalysts. The carbon nanofiber network significantly contributes to the increase of the support surface area [40,41], which in turn, improves the catalytic performance, and also enhance the ability of the catalyst to evacuate the reaction heat through higher heat transfer [42,43]. The aim of this present work is to report the synthesis of defective carbon nanotubes decorated macroscopic carbon felt with high specific surface area and controlled macroscopic shape for the selective oxidation of H2S under a direct and non-contact inductive heating mode. This macroscopic composite significantly facilitates the transport and handling of the catalyst which was not the case for the carbon nanotubes with powdery morphology. Indeed, carbon nanotubes-based metal-free catalysts cannot be foreseen as viable catalysts for industrial due to their inherent drawbacks: powdery morphology which hinders safety manipulation and the associated large pressure drop when operated in industrial fixed-bed reactor. In the macroscopic composite developed in this work the large open structure of the carbon felt as macroscopic host matrix significantly contributes to the reduction of the problem linked with pressure drop across the catalyst bed, especially when the reaction was carried out at high gaseous space velocity. In addition, it is worthy to note that the carbon felt host substrate not only acting as macroscopic host substrate for the high effective surface carbon nanotubes but also as an intrinsic susceptor for a homogeneous and rapid heating of the catalyst under inductive heating mode. Such direct and non-contact heating mode also allows one to avoid large heat consumption to heat up the gaseous reactant before entering the catalyst bed as encountered with traditional JH mode and thus, the total delivered heat is devoted to the reaction. Such specific heating mode could significantly improve the overall heat efficiency for the process. The as-synthesized metal-free carbon-based catalyst displays high catalytic performance and high stability as a function of severe reaction conditions, i.e. low reaction temperature and high gaseous velocity, under IH mode compared to the same catalyst operated under JH mode. Long-term evaluation also confirms the high stability of the catalyst for operating selective oxidation of H2S into elemental sulfur. 2 Experimental section 2.1 Carbon nanotubes@carbon felt synthesis The growth catalyst was prepared by wetness impregnation of the carbon felt (CF, Mersen Com.) with an aqueous solution of iron nitrate (Fe(NO3)3, Fluka) with a theoretical metal loading of 5 wt. %. The as-impregnated sample was dried at room-temperature for 2 h and oven-dried at 110 °C for additional 2 h. It was then calcined in air at 300 °C for 2 h in order to transform the iron nitrate into its corresponding oxide. The Fe2O3/CF catalyst was then reduced in-situ under hydrogen flow (200 mL. min−1) at 400 °C for 2 h and then, the reactor temperature was raised to the carbon nanotubes synthesis temperature, i.e. 720, 750 and 780 °C, with a heating rate of 10 °C. min−1, under hydrogen. At the synthesis temperature the hydrogen flow was replaced by a C2H6/H2 mixture (50:50 sccm. min−1) and the synthesis was lasted for 3 h, and the reactor was cooled from the synthesis temperature to 200 °C under the reactant mixture and from 200 °C to room-temperature under argon flow. The iron growth catalyst was removed from the composite by treatment in liquid HNO3 acid at 80 °C for 6 h followed by a washing step with distilled water at room-temperature until neutral pH was reached [44]. The TEM analysis reported in our previous work has evidenced the presence of some isolated iron carbide, completely encapsulated by graphite layers, inside the carbon nanotubes channel. The concentration of the residual iron catalyst was analyzed by elemental analysis and it contributed to ca. 0.1−0.2 wt.% of the sample. It cannot be ruled out at this state of investigation about the contribution of such iron species in the heat management of the catalyst. However, according to the relatively low amount of the encapsulated iron species one should expected that the associated heat should be relatively low compared to that generated by the eddy current on the carbon-based sample. 2.2 Defective generation through gaseous HNO3 treatment For the gaseous acid treatment 2 g of CNT@CF (in a form of disks) were loaded inside a tubular reactor (16 × 100 mm) and heated to the desired temperature at 250 °C by an external furnace. The treatment temperature was controlled by a thermocouple inserted inside the furnace. The reactor containing CNT@CF was connected to a round bottom flask filled with 150 mL of HNO3 with a concentration of 65 %. The temperature of the round bottom flask was fixed at 125 °C and the HNO3 solution was keep under magnetic stirring. The gaseous acid, carried by a flow of 10 mL/min of argon, passed upward through the CNT@CF composite was further condensed in another flask which can be re-used for the process. The acid activation process was carried out for 4 h and the activated catalyst was recovered and evaluated in catalytic process without any post-treatment. The unreacted HNO3 can be re-used for other activation process. 2.3 Characterization techniques The scanning electron microscopy (SEM) was carried out on a ZEISS Gemini 2600 F with a resolution of 5 nm. The sample was deposited onto a double face graphite tape in order to avoid charging effect during the analysis. The TEM analysis was carried out on a JEOL 2100 F working at 200 kV accelerated voltage, equipped with a probe corrector for spherical aberrations, and a point-to-point resolution of 0.2 nm. The sample was dispersed by ultrasounds in an ethanol solution for 5 min and a drop of the solution was deposited on a copper covered with a holey carbon membrane for observation. The specific surface area of the support and the catalyst, after reduction, were determined in a Micromeritics sorptometer. The sample was outgassed at 250 °C under vacuum for 8 h in order to desorb moisture and adsorbed species on its surface. Physisorption measurements were carried out using N2 as adsorbent at −196 °C under a relative pressure between 0.06 and 0.99. The pore size distribution was calculated from the desorption branch of the isotherm. The Raman spectra were recorded using LabRAM ARAMIS Horiba Raman spectrometer equipment. Spectra were recorded over the range of 500–4000 cm−1 at the laser excitation wavelength of 532 nm. The sample was deposited on glass substrate by deep-coating of its suspension and carefully dried before measurement. Thermal gravimetric analysis (TGA) was realized on a TGA Q5000 instrument with a heating rate of 10 °C/min under air atmosphere. The weight of the sample was keep at around 10 mg in order to avoid diffusion problems during the analysis. 2.4 H2S selective oxidation process The H2S oxidation process can be outlined according to the following main Eqs. [1]–[3]. In the present study, H2S selective oxidation to elemental sulfur (Eq. [1]) was promoted by a catalyst located within a glass tubular reactor working isothermally under atmospheric pressure. (1) H2S + ½ O2 → 1/n Sn + H2OΔH = – 222 kJ/mol (2) S + O2 → SO2ΔH = – 297 kJ/mol (3) H2S + 3 O2 → 2 SO2 + 2 H2OΔH =–381 kJ/mol To this aim two disks of o-CNT@o-CF (Vcat 7.5 cm3) were loaded on a silica wool located in a tubular Pyrex reactor (inner ∅: 16 mm) and housed inside an electrical oven or inside an inductive coil. The catalyst temperature was controlled by a thermocouple coupled with a Minicor regulator. The reactants gas mixture [H2S (1 vol.%), O2 (2.5 vol.%), H2O (30 vol.%) in inert He as carrier (balance)] was passed downward through the catalyst bed through Brooks 5850TR mass flow controllers. Steam (30 vol.%) in the reactant feed was ensured by bubbling the inert carrier in a saturator containing hot water at 80 °C. The use of a relatively high concentration of steam in the feed is motivated by the will to be as close as possible to the industrial working conditions as the steam formed during the former Claus units is not removed before the oxidation step and remains in the treated tail gas. Previous results have shown that steam concentration had almost no influence on the H2S conversion while at low steam concentration a slight improvement of the sulfur selectivity was observed [35]. The space velocity was fixed between 18,000 and 22,000 mL/gcatalyst/h, and the O2-to-H2S molar ratio was kept constant to 2.5. All catalytic runs were carried out in continuous mode. Hence, mostly of the formed elemental sulfur was vaporized (because of the high partial pressure of sulfur at the reaction temperatures) and condensed alongside with steam at the catalyst outlet. The analysis of the inlet and outlet gases was performed on-line using a Varian CP-3800 gas chromatograph (GC) equipped with a Chrompack CP-SilicaPLOT capillary column and a thermal catharometer detector (TCD) for the detection of O2, H2S, H2O and SO2 (the detection limit for the sulfur compounds is 50 ppm). H2S and SO2 concentrations were recalculated on the basis of the corrected flow after steam condensation. All the connecting lines were wrapped with thermal tapes maintained at 140 °C in order to prevent any adsorption of the reaction products. The schematic representation of the micropilot setup is presented in Scheme 1 . The induction heating setup (EasyHeat® 8310, 10 kW, Ambrell Ltd) is constituted by a spiral 6-turn induction coil (length = 1.05 m, pure coil resistance = 2.066 × 10−3 Ω), cooled by means of an external chiller with recirculated water/glycerol (10 %) mixture. In a typical experiment, the glass reactor containing the catalyst, similar to the one used for the JH, was housed inside the induction heater coils and temperature real-time control/regulation was ensured by a PID system (Proportional Integral Derivative controller, Eurotherm model 3504) connected to a laser pyrometer (Optris®, spectral range of 1.8–2.3 μm, ∅ laser beam: ≈ 500 μm, power < 1 mW, located at ≈ 30 cm from the catalyst) shot up on the catalyst bed and working in the 150–1000 °C range (accuracy ± 3 °C). The heating/cooling rate allowed for the system is 60−80 °C min-1 in the 160−300 °C temperature range. It is worthy to note that the inductor operated at a frequency of 263 kHz which generated a much lower magnetic field compared to those operated at lower frequency, i.e. < 10 kHz [45,46]. It is worthy to note that magnetic fields from low frequency induction are more penetrating to the surrounding material. In order to reduce the exposure of the worker to the magnetic field the setup was localized inside a Faraday cage. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Supports characteristics The digital photos of the different supports used are presented in Fig. 1 , i.e. macroscopic carbon felt (Fig. 1A–C) and carbon nanotubes (Fig. 1A, D and E), which highlights the advantage of combining the carbon felt as a macroscopic host substrate and carbon nanotubes, with high effective surface area with increasing active site density per exposed surface unit for carrying out the catalytic reaction. Such hierarchical structured composite facilitates the transport and handling and also significantly reduces the problem of pressure drop across the catalyst bed despite the presence of carbon with nanoscopic dimension in the catalyst. 3.2 Catalyst characteristics The representative SEM images of the CNT@CF composite synthesized by a CVD method are presented in Fig. 2 . For the sake of clarity, the SEM image of the carbon felt treated under inert gas at the same synthesis temperature is also reported to confirm the conservation of the macroscopic morphology of the host substrate upon high temperature annealing process (Fig. 2A). According to the SEM analysis, the surface of the carbon microfilaments is gradually covered with aggregates bundles of CNT as increasing the reaction temperature (Fig. 2B–D). The CNT coverage seems to be relatively homogeneous for the synthesis temperature of 750 and 780 °C leading to a slight increase of the mean diameter of the carbon microfilament (Fig. 2C and D). High resolution SEM image of the CNT@CF-750 shows the presence of a relatively dense web-like structure of CNT on the topmost surface of the CF microfilament (Fig. 2E). The formed CNT also displays a very homogeneous diameter ranged at ca. 80 ± 10 nm with a high aspect ratio which is in good agreement with the previous results [44]. The CNT network also displays a relatively high mechanical strength as a weight loss of only 2 wt.% was observed after an ultrasonication step in a mixture of ethanol:water (20:80 v:v %) for 15 min. Such high anchorage behavior was attributed to the growth mechanism of the CNT on the carbon felt host matrix. Indeed, during the growth process, part of the CNT formed from the iron nanoparticle could penetrate the carbon felt filamentous, i.e. playing the role of roof, and thus, significantly improves the mechanical anchorage of the CNT network on the host matrix [47]. Such mechanical anchorage could also be explained by the presence of an intermediate phase, i.e. microporous carbon layer which is strongly anchored on the host matrix surface [48]. The CNT yield and specific surface area (SSA) of the CNT@CF composites as a function of the synthesis temperature are summarized in Table 1 . The introduction of a layer of CNT on the CF host matrix surface leads to a significant increase of the overall SSA of the composite compared to that of the pristine CF, i.e. 4 m2 g−1. Such increase of the SSA was directly attributed to the high effective surface area of the nanoscopic CNT on the microfilamentous structure of the CF which is in good agreement with the literature reports on such kind of composites [49–51]. Indeed, the intrinsic specific surface area of the carbon nanofibers/nanotubes is usually ranged between 80 and 200 m2. g−1 [50,51]. However, it is worthy to note that at high synthesis temperature, i.e. 780 °C, and despite the continuous increase of the CNT yield, the SSA of the composite steadily decreased from 49 to 33 m2. g−1 for a CNT yield of 105 and 120 wt. % (Table 1). Such SSA decreases as increasing the synthesis temperature and the CNT yield could be attributed to the increase of the CNT average diameter and also to a higher entanglement of the CNT network which could reduce the accessible surface area for the adsorbent [52]. For these reasons only the CNT@CF sample synthesized at 750 °C will be characterized in detail and evaluated for the catalytic selective oxidation of H2S. The corresponding SEM and TEM images of the acid-treated CNT-CF-750 sample at 250 °C are presented in Fig. 3 A and B. The SEM image confirms the complete conservation of the sample morphology after acid treatment displaying the hairy structure (Fig. 3A) while the TEM image evidences the formation of structural defects along the CNT axis (indicated by arrows in Fig. 3B). The formation of defects inside the CNT structure is in good agreement with the decrease of the graphitic G band on the acid treated sample as evidenced by the Raman analysis (see below). However, it is noted that the tubular morphology of the CNT is still conserved which indicated that acid treatment only etches the carbon layer on the outer surface of the tube through defects formation without breaking it (Fig. 3C and D), and thus, allows one to conserve the hierarchical structure of the composite for subsequence catalytic applications. The mass loss, consecutive to the oxidative reaction between the carbon species and the acid vapor, after the acid treatment and the SSA of the different samples are summarized in Table 2 . The acid treatment leads to a significant increase of the SSA of the sample which is directly attributed to the creation of defects on the carbon structure. However, the defects location may vary from sample to sample: on the o-CF the defects are generated inside the microfilament, with an average diameter at around 10 μm, which are less accessible compared to the defects generated on the CNT, with an average diameter ranged between 0.08 to 0.1 μm. It is expected that such defect location among the tested catalysts could play an important role on the catalytic performance. The difference in terms of SSA between the o-CF and the o-CNT@o-CF samples could be explained by the difference in terms of graphitization between the two samples as the higher graphitization of the CNT could prevent depth corrosion during the acid treatment. In addition, the CF was largely covered by a dense network of CNT which could prevent it from the corrosion by the acid. Such phenomenon could be also evidenced by the lower weight loss of the o-CNT@o-CF sample compared to that of the o-CF (Table 2). Some micropores were generated inside the o-CF but they are mostly localized on the top surface of the fiber. The survey XPS spectra of the different samples are presented in Fig. 4 A and indicated an increase of the oxygenated functional groups on the o-CNT@o-CF sample which is probably generated on the defects. The high-resolution O1s spectra with the nature of the different oxygenated functional groups and the total oxygen content, determined by the deconvolution of the XPS O1s spectra, of the CNT@CF and acid-treated o-CNT@o-CF, are presented in Fig. 4B. The oxygen concentration in the o-CNT@o-CF is the highest among the acid treated samples (Fig. 4C). Such results can be explained by the fact that during the acid treatment the oxygenated functional groups were generated and stabilized on the structural defects [35]. The Raman spectra of the CF, CNT@CF and o-CNT@o-CF samples are presented in Fig. 4D. On the pristine CF sample, the D band (corresponding to the sp3 disordered carbon) is similar to the G band (corresponding to the sp2 ordered carbon) which indicates the balance between the two forms of carbon in the sample [53,54]. After the introduction of CNT a slight increase of the G band was observed and could be attributed to the graphitic structure of the CNT incorporated inside the sample. On the o-CNT@o-CF sample a large decrease of the G band was observed which can be ascribed to the generation of defects in the sample upon acid treatment leading to the loss of the graphitic character of the pristine sample, especially the one linked with the CNT structure. Such results are in good agreement with those obtained by TEM and XPS discussed above. 3.3 Heating behavior of the o-CNT@o-CF under inductive heating The heating behavior was measured on a square sample connected with two electrodes as depicted in Fig. 5 A. The thermal responsive of the CF (20 mm x 20 mm x 6 mm, R = 1.5 Ω) and CNT@CF (20 mm x 20 mm x 6 mm, R = 0.9 Ω) samples under an external applied voltage was investigated using Forward Looking InfraRed (FLIR) camera (Fig. 5A1 and A2). The temperature of the two samples steadily increases as soon as a voltage of 1.5 V was applied to the sample to reach a steady-state at 80 °C for the CNT@CF (intensity of 1.7 A) vs 45 °C for the pristine CF (intensity of 0.6 A). Such difference in terms of temperature between the CNT@CF and CF samples was attributed to the improvement of the interconnection within the CNT@CF sample thanks to the presence of a highly entangled carbon CNT inside the catalyst. The CNT@CF sample also displays a higher apparent heat homogeneity compared to that of the pristine CF which could be attributed to a higher interconnectivity within the sample through CNT bridging. Such high heat transfer could represent a net advantage for the sample to reduce the formation of local hot spot during the catalytic process and also to provide a homogeneous heat within the sample under inductive heating process. The reactor configuration under the reaction is presented in Fig. 5B. In addition, as evidenced by the infrared (IR) photo in Fig. 5C the temperature is generated only in the catalyst part which is located inside the inductive coil and drops in a dramatic manner after few centimeters of distance from both sides of the catalyst. Such results can be directly attributed to the high heat targeting ability of the IH which can thus provide heat to a specific target and not to heat up the whole setup as well as the gaseous reactant as encountered with the JH. The high heat responsive monitoring of the laser pyrometer and the high heating rate of the inductive coil also provide a high regulation of the catalyst temperature and to prevent any local temperature runaway within the catalyst. 3.4 H2S selective oxidation The desulfurization performance of the different catalysts, o-CF and o-CNT@o-CF-750, as a function of time-on-stream is reported in Fig. 6 . The desulfurization performance, expressed in terms of H2S conversion, follows the sequence: o-CNT@o-CF-750 > o-CF. Blank test carried out on the CF shows no desulfurization activity (H2S conversion = 0 % and thus is not reported) and confirms the ability of the carbon containing defects to perform the selective oxidation process. The o-CNT@o-CF-750 displays the highest H2S conversion and intermediate sulfur selectivity which could be attributed to the combination of the high exposure of active site, thanks to the nanoscopic dimension of the CNT coated layer, and the higher porosity conferred by the CF host substrate as discussed above. Indeed, in the case of o-CF part of the defects localized far from the surface seems not to be effectively involved, probably due to the problem of diffusion, while those present on the o-CNT@o-CF-750 are more accessible thanks to the very short diffusion path, i.e. nanometer length (see discussion below). The o-CF displays a slightly higher sulfur selectivity which could be attributed to the lower H2S conversion and to the higher porosity of the sample which could favor the escaping of the intermediate sulfur product. The results clearly evidenced the advantages of using hybrid nano-macro structured catalyst for the desulfurization process as it combines on one side, the high exposure of the active site thanks to the nanoscopic dimension of the surrounding o-CNT, and on the other side, a structured catalyst with macroscopic shape which facilitate the transport and handling and also to prevent pressure drop across the catalyst bed when operating the reaction in fixed-bed configuration. Similar results have also been reported through the macronization of CNT in a foam shape which displayed high accessibility along with controlled shape [55]. In the following section the desulfurization performance of the o-CNT@o-CF-750 catalyst, which is the most active ones, will be thoroughly investigated under different reaction conditions and under both JH and IH mode in order to take profit of the advantages derived from a combination of carbon-based metal-free catalyst and inductive heating mode. 3.4.1 Influence of the reaction temperature The influence of the reaction temperature on the desulfurization performance of the o-CNT@o-CF-750 catalyst under JH and IH mode is presented in Fig. 7 A. Under JH mode the H2S conversion at 230 °C is extremely high, leveled-off to about 99.8 %, and remains stable during ca. 30 h of test. Decreasing the reaction temperature from 230 °C to 210 °C significantly lowers the H2S conversion on the o-CNT@o-CF-750 catalyst from 99.8 % to 87 %. The decrease of the desulfurization performance could be attributed to a decrease of the surface temperature of the catalyst, consecutive to the heat exchange with the reactant flow. For comparison, the desulfurization results obtained on the same catalyst but under IH mode is presented in Fig. 7B. A clear improvement in terms of catalytic performance was observed when operating the catalyst under IH mode: the desulfurization performance, expressed in terms of H2S conversion, remains almost unchanged when the reaction temperature was decreased from 230 °C (H2S conversion of 99.8 %) to 210 °C (H2S conversion of 97.8 %) and finally to 200 °C (H2S conversion of 83.8 %). The return test at 230 °C completely restore the desulfurization performance and confirm that irreversible deactivation by the loss of the active phase is unlikely in the present case. It is also worthy to note that no deactivation was observed on the catalyst for both heating modes which confirms the high stability of such metal-free carbon-based catalysts for selective desulfurization process. Such high desulfurization performance when operated under IH mode can be attributed to the high efficiency of the IH to generate and maintain heat directly and rapidly inside the catalyst bed which prevents heat loss from transfer between the oven and the catalyst, and also to the surface temperature loss through gaseous heat exchange, as encountered with JH mode due to the high inertia of the oven to compensate temperature loss in the catalyst bed. It is worthy to mention that for IH mode the entry reactant flow temperature has no influence on the reactivity as the flow entered the catalyst bed at almost room-temperature and only the catalyst bed was maintained at the reaction temperature. The heat generated inside the catalyst is thus directly compensated by the inductive coil to maintain the set temperature for the reaction which significantly reduces heat transfer resistance as encountered with the JH mode. Such difference in terms of heat management is probably at the origin of the high desulfurization performance of the o-CNT@o-CF-750 catalyst as a function of the reaction temperature when operated under IH mode. The nanoscopic dimension of the CNT could also provide better heat generation through eddy currents (skin heating effect) within the catalyst which could significantly improve the catalytic performance [56,57]. In addition, the all-carbon catalyst with high thermal conductivity is easily activated by IH which provides high temperature control, and to reduce the problem linked with heat transfer resistance in the solid catalyst contrary to that occurred with other insulator catalysts due to the poor heat transfer inside the insulator catalyst [7]. The high thermal conductivity of the carbon-based catalyst also significantly reduces problems linked with local formation of hot spots which ultimately leads to rapid deactivation as well as temperature runaway which are at the origin of the low catalytic performance and unsecure catalytic process [58]. The sulfur selectivity on the o-CNT@o-CF-750 catalyst is about 80 % at 230 °C and 85 % at 210 °C which remain similar to those reported for nitrogen-doped metal-free carbon catalysts (Table 3 ). Such results could be attributed to the relatively high desulfurization activity of the catalyst which generated large amount of sulfur on the catalyst surface and thus, could favor the secondary reaction between the H2S or the formed sulfur and excess oxygen in the reactant flow. Table 3 summarized some literature results for desulfurization process on nitrogen-doped carbon-based catalysts and those obtained in the present work. According to the results the defective undoped o-CNT@o-CF-750 catalyst displays similar desulfurization performance compared to the N-doped catalysts and thus, highlighted the possibility of developing such hierarchical defective doping-free carbon-based catalysts for desulfurization processes as well as for other oxidation processes. 3.4.2 Influence of the reactant space velocity In heterogeneous catalysis the catalytic performance is strongly influenced by the reactant gaseous space velocity due to the lowering of the contact time but also to the artificial increase of heat removal through solid-gas exchange process on the catalyst surface at high gas flow rate. Under JH the low inertia of the oven is unable to maintain the reaction temperature inside the catalyst bed, especially at the catalyst surface temperature, which could lead to a net decrease of the catalytic performance despite no deactivation was observed. According to the discussion above one should expected that IH could be the heating mode of choice for operating the reaction under high reactant gaseous velocity as the reaction temperature was adjusted constantly by the inductor which is not the case for the JH mode. The results obtained as a function of the GHSV under JH mode on the o-CNT@o-CF-750 catalyst are presented in Fig. 8 A. Under JH mode the increase of the space velocity of the reactant, from 18,000, 20,000 and finally to 22,000 mL. gcat −1. h−1, leads to a drastic decrease of the H2S conversion from 99.9 % to 84.0 % and then to 70.0 % which could be attributed to the reducing of the contact time between the reactant and the catalyst and also to the surface temperature loss through the enhanced heat exchange with the gas phase, which cannot be compensated by the JH mode, due to the low feedback and to the low inertia of the oven, as discussed above. It is worthy to note that despite the loss of the desulfurization performance upon increasing the space velocity no deactivation, as a function of time-on-stream under the same space velocity, was observed which confirms again the high stability of the catalyst. The decrease of the H2S conversion was accompanied with a slight improvement for the sulfur selectivity as the reduction of the contact time favors the escaping of the sulfur intermediate product from the catalyst surface which reduces the secondary reaction to form SO2. On the same catalyst operated under IH mode the desulfurization performance remains almost unchanged as increasing the reactant space velocity from 18,000 to 22,000 mL. gcat −1. h−1 which again confirms the complete maintaining of the catalyst temperature under IH mode unlikely to that observed under JH mode (Fig. 8B). The H2S conversion under IH mode remains at 99 % versus 84 % for the sample operated under JH mode, at a space velocity of 20,000 mL. gcat −1. h−1. A higher difference can be observed at higher GHSV as depicted in Fig. 8B. It is expected that under IH regulation the temperature variation on the catalyst surface was rapidly regulated through rapid heating adjustment which thus, allows the maintaining of the reaction temperature regardless the reaction parameters modification, i.e. enhancement of the heat removal through gas-solid exchange phenomena due to the increase of the reactant flow rate [66]. The desulfurization performance decrease at high space velocity (Fig. 8B(iii)) could be attributed to the insufficient residence time of the reactant in the system which is independent to the heating mode. 3.4.3 Influence of the O2-to-H2S ratio In the desulfurization process parameters such as the H2S concentration or the O2-to-H2S ratio, could be fluctuated depending to the emitting source which could have an influence on the catalyst stability, especially for metal oxide based catalyst due to the problem of surface sulfidation. In order to assess the ability of the defective carbon-based metal-free catalyst in regard of such fluctuation the influence of the O2-to-H2S ratio was investigated on the catalyst under both heating modes. According to the results a significant improvement of the desulfurization performance was observed for the catalyst operated under IH mode compared to the same operated under JH mode (Fig. 9 ). On the catalyst operated under IH mode the H2S conversion remains almost unchanged as a function of the O2-to-H2S ratio while the sulfur selectivity slightly increased due to the lower oxygen availability for directing the secondary reaction to generate SO2. It is also worthy to note that both catalysts display high desulfurization stability as a function of the O2-to-H2S ratio which indicated that active phase nature modification is unlikely to occur. Such results could be attributed to the high activity of the defective sites decorated with oxygenated functional groups, as active centers for oxygen dissociation which provides enough oxygen to catalyze the selective oxidation process. The slightly higher H2S conversion observed under IH mode at low O2-to-H2S ratio could be attributed to the better and homogeneous heat maintaining under IH mode which could maintain the oxygen dissociation rate on the active site. 3.4.4 Long-term stability The stability of the o-CNT@o-CF-750 catalyst operated under IH mode, at reaction temperature of 210 °C and 230 °C, was also conducted for ca. 100 h and the results are presented in Fig. 10 . The catalyst displays an extremely high stability as a function of time-on-stream, especially at reaction temperature of 230 °C (Fig. 10A), which indicates that such macroscopic structured carbon metal- and doping-free catalyst can be efficiently used for desulfurization process under IH mode. The slight decrease of the H2S conversion observed at 210 °C could be attributed to some solid sulfur deposit on the catalyst surface which could partially block the active site access (Fig. 10B). On the other hand, operated the selective oxidation process at 230 °C could significantly reduce the sulfur deposition and thus, leading to a stable catalytic performance as a function of time-on-stream (Fig. 10A). Similar results have also been reported recently by Li et al. [67] on defective nitrogen-doped carbon catalyst where no deactivation was observed under different reaction conditions and time-on-stream. The spent catalyst, after the long-term test, was characterized by BET and SEM and the SEM results are presented in Fig. 11 and confirm the statement made above. The SSA displays noticeable change after the reaction at 210 °C, i.e. 90 m2. g−1 instead of 180 m2 g−1, due to the sulfur deposition on the catalyst, according to the SEM analysis. Indeed, the SEM micrographs obtained on the sample after reaction at 210 °C show the presence of solid sulfur clusters on the spent catalyst, due to the high temperature gradient inside the catalyst bed, but the gross morphology of the sample was retained (Fig. 11A). The sulfur particles located on the CF fibers are highlighted in yellow for the sake of clarity. However, it is worthy to note that SEM analysis on the catalyst operated at 230 °C displays much lower sulfur deposition which confirms the high performance of the catalyst for the selective oxidation process and the stability as a function of time-on-stream (Fig. 11B and C). The catalyst weight, measured before and after ca. 100 h of time-on-stream, remains almost unchanged, i.e. ± 1 wt.%, which highlighted the stability of such metal-free carbon catalyst for the process. Similar results have also been reported recently by Duong-Viet et al. [68] on the nitrogen-doped carbon operated for more than 600 h of reaction. The SSA of the catalyst tested at 230 °C was about 140 m2/g which confirms the low porosity plugging by sulfur compared to that observed for the sample operated at 210 °C. The TGA spectrum of the spent catalyst, after catalytic test at 230 °C for 100 h, displays a relatively low sulfur deposit on the catalyst, i.e. 2 wt. % (Fig. 11D). The high resistance towards oxidation of the sample, as depicted by the TGA results (Fig. 11D), prevents the degradation of the active phase in the presence of excess oxygen in the processing feed at the reaction temperature, and allows one to explain the high stability of the metal-free carbon catalyst for the selective oxidation of H2S into elemental sulfur. 4 Conclusion In summary, we have succeeded to synthesize composite consisted of a dense layer of carbon nanotubes coated on a macroscopic carbon felt with high mechanical stability and high accessibility for being used further as metal-free catalyst for the selective oxidation of H2S into elemental sulfur. The gaseous HNO3 post-synthesis treatment allows one to create structural defects decorated with oxygenated functional groups on the CNT surface, as well as on the carbon felt host substrate, which significantly modify the overall physical properties of these metal-free catalysts but also their desulfurization activity. The controlled macroscopic shape of the host substrate provides a clever way to produce metal-free catalyst with competitive advantages compared to the powdery defective carbon nanotubes catalyst such as easy transport and handling with low hazardous effect, low pressure drop and channeling for operating fixed-bed processes along with long-term stability. The carbon-based catalyst can also be directly used as both catalyst and susceptor under electrical driven inductive heating which represents an interesting path for the development of targeted heating catalyst with high heat control and low energy waste. Under inductive heating the as-synthesized defective metal-free catalyst displays a high desulfurization performance, both in terms of activity but also stability, for the selective oxidation process to convert harmful H2S into valuable elemental sulfur at low reaction temperature and under relatively high reactant gaseous velocity compared to the same catalyst operated under Joule heating mode. The direct heat generated within the all-carbon catalyst matrix significantly reduces the problem of heat transfer resistance and thus, conferring to the catalyst operated under IH mode a higher efficiency. In addition, heat is produced mostly on the surface of the catalyst where the reaction takes place which also contribute to the reduction of heat loss. The nanoscopic dimension of the carbon nanotubes also provides a higher heat in the system through eddy currents which provide higher active site density to operate the reaction. The targeted heat exclusively to the solid catalyst could also modify the product adsorption leading to an improved catalytic system. The heating zone can be merely dissociated with respect to the reaction operation conditions, as only the catalyst is heated, and thus, it is expected that such catalyst and susceptor can be also efficiently used in the field of liquid-phase reaction in which the catalyst surface temperature can be tuned regardless the medium temperature. In addition, it is worthy to emphasize that such system can be operated with green energy source, i.e. exceeding electricity issued from renewable energy instead of using natural gas fired furnace where a large amount of heat loss was encountered along with large production of greenhouse gas by-product. The simplicity of the IH setup could be also advantageous for operating small factory with high flexibility as a function of demand in place of traditional large plants. Work is ongoing to evaluate the ability of such all-carbon catalyst for the catalytic oxidation of trace amount of H2S into SO2 at low reaction temperature for sulfuric acid process which represents a most economically viable process for the valorization of H2S in a flue gas. coredata.dc:description: Hierarchical all carbon metal-free catalyst with controlled macroscopic shape based on the carbon nanotubes decorated carbon felt (CNT@CF) has been prepared. The catalyst was further treated under gaseous nitric acid to generate structural defects on its surface (o-CNT@o-CF). The as-synthesized catalyst was evaluated in the partial oxidation of H2S by oxygen into elemental sulfur in a fixed-bed reactor under a direct and non-contact inductive heating mode. The catalytic results indicate that the o-CNT@o-CF catalyst exhibits an extremely high desulfurization performance under inductive heating mode. The high desulfurization performance was attributed to the high effective heat management inside the catalyst through inductive heating along with a short diffusion length associated with the nanoscopic dimension of the carbon nanotubes. The catalyst also displays a high stability as a function of time on stream.
coredata.dc:title: Radiofrequency-driven selective oxidation of H2S on hierarchical metal-free catalyst containing defects
